Topic: Draw reversible and irreversible changes (ice melting vs. egg cooking)
Evidence Statements: The student can show a material before it is heated or cooled.
The student can illustrate and label what happens to the material after it is heated (e.g., ice turns to water or an egg cooks).
The student can illustrate and label what happens to the material after it is cooled (e.g., water freezes back to ice).
The student can show whether the change from heating or cooling is reversible or irreversible (e.g., water can freeze back to ice, but a cooked egg cannot become raw again).
The student can identify and label causes of the changes (e.g., heating or cooling) in their drawing.
The student can represent an argument or claim in their drawing by including evidence showing whether the changes are reversible or irreversible.
